r = r_s text( defines the event horizon)

explanation: The Schwarzschild radius defines the event horizon of a black hole - the critical radius where the escape velocity equals the speed of light. Named after Karl Schwarzschild, who found the first exact solution to Einstein's field equations, it represents the boundary beyond which nothing, not even light, can escape the gravitational pull. This fundamental length scale determines when an object becomes a black hole and governs the most extreme gravitational environments in the universe.
assumptions: No electric charge (Schwarzschild solution, not Reissner-Nordström).
General relativity is the correct theory of gravity.
The mass M is concentrated within the Schwarzschild radius.
Energy conservation applies in the classical derivation.
The speed of light is the maximum possible velocity.
General relativity provides the correct spacetime geometry.
The Schwarzschild solution is the appropriate metric.

derivation.description: Begin with the classical concept of escape velocity.
Set kinetic energy equal to gravitational potential energy.
Solve for the escape velocity as a function of radius.
Impose the condition that escape velocity equals the speed of light.
derivation.equation: text(Set escape velocity equal to speed of light)

derivation.description: Set up the equation with escape velocity equal to c.
Square both sides to eliminate the square root.
Solve for the critical radius (Schwarzschild radius).
The rigorous derivation comes from the Schwarzschild metric in general relativity.
derivation.equation: text(General relativistic derivation from Schwarzschild metric)

derivation.description: Write the Schwarzschild metric in standard coordinates.
Identify where the metric coefficient becomes singular.
This coordinate singularity defines the event horizon radius.

historical_context.importance: Defines black hole event horizons, crucial for understanding gravitational collapse, Hawking radiation, and modern astrophysics
key_insights: Karl Schwarzschild found exact solution to Einstein field equations
Discovered shortly after Einstein published general relativity
Schwarzschild died in WWI shortly after his discovery
Event horizon concept developed much later (1950s-1960s)
